Situation1: Their partner is going through a serious personal crisis and relies on them for consistent emotional reassurance and presence.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, my wife’s eyes red and tired as she tried to hold herself together. She needed me—really needed me—now more than ever. Her father’s illness had shaken her to the core, and every night she reached for my hand, searching for comfort, for someone to lean on. I wanted to be there, to listen, to reassure her that we’d get through this together.

But at work, a new notice had gone up: an optional training session next week, right after our shift. The foreman made it clear that those who attended would be first in line for overtime and new projects. The guys were already talking about how important it was to show up, to prove you’re committed. I could feel the pressure mounting—if I missed it, I’d be letting the team down, maybe even risking my spot on the next big job.

I stared at the calendar, the training circled in red, the same night my wife had her father’s specialist appointment. My chest tightened as I tried to figure out how I could possibly be in two places at once.
